revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox film | name = The Age of Adaline | image = The Age of Adaline film poster.png | image_size = | caption = Theatrical release poster | film name = | director = [[Lee Toland Krieger]] | producer = [[Sidney Kimmel]]
[[Gary Lucchesi]]
[[Tom Rosenberg]] | writer = [[J. Mills Goodloe]]
[[Salvador Paskowitz]] | starring = [[Blake Lively]]
[[Michiel Huisman]]
[[Kathy Baker]]
[[Harrison Ford]]
[[Ellen Burstyn]] | narrator = Hugh Ross | music = [[Rob Simonsen]] | cinematography = David Lanzenberg | editing = Melissa Kent | studio = [[Lakeshore Entertainment]]
[[Sidney Kimmel Entertainment]] | distributor = [[Lionsgate Films|Lionsgate]] | released = {{Film date|2015|04|24|United States}} | runtime = 113 minutes{{cite web | url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/age-adaline-film | title=''THE AGE OF ADALINE'' (12A) | work=[[British Board of Film Classification]] | date=April 24, 2018 | accessdate=April 24, 2015}} | country = United States | language = English | budget = $25 million{{cite web|url=https://pro-labs.imdb.com/name/nm0401264?rf=cons_nm_contact&ref_=cons_nm_contact|title=Michiel Huisman|work=imdb.com}} | gross = $65.7 million{{cite web |url= http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=ageofadaline.htm|title= The Age of Adaline (2015) |publisher= [[Amazon.com]] | work = [[Box Office Mojo]] |accessdate=June 16, 2016}} }} '''''The Age of Adaline''''' is a 2015 American [[Romance film|romantic]] [[fantasy film]] directed by [[Lee Toland Krieger]] and written by [[J. Mills Goodloe]] and [[Salvador Paskowitz]]. The film stars [[Blake Lively]] in the title role, with [[Michiel Huisman]], [[Kathy Baker]], [[Amanda Crew]], [[Harrison Ford]], and [[Ellen Burstyn]] in supporting roles. Narrated by Hugh Ross, the story follows Adaline Bowman, a young woman who stops aging after an accident at the age of 29. The film was co-produced by [[Sidney Kimmel Entertainment]] and [[Lakeshore Entertainment]]. In October 2013, Lively was cast as the title character, with Krieger attached to direct. [[Principal photography]] took place in [[Vancouver]] from March 5, 2014 to May 5. ''The Age of Adaline'' premiered in [[New York City]] on April 19, 2015 was theatrically released on April 24 in the United States by [[Lionsgate Films|Lionsgate]]. The film received mixed reviews from critics, with many praising the performances of Lively and Ford respectively and was frequently cited as some of their best work in recent years. It was a modest box-office success, grossing $65.7 million worldwide on a $25 million budget. The film received two nominations at the [[42nd Saturn Awards]], one for [[Saturn Award for Best Fantasy Film|Best Fantasy Film]] and one for Lively for [[Saturn Award for Best Actress|Best Actress]]. ==Plot== One afternoon in [[San Francisco]], Adaline Bowman purchases fake IDs at an apartment before returning home to feed her dog. She then goes to work and opens a box of film reels, which highlight historical events and times. A voiceover ties together the film reels explaining the story of Adaline's life so far. She was born on New Years Day 1908, then later married and gave birth to a daughter, only to become a widow after her husband died in a tragic accident. Years later, in 1937, Adaline crashed her car when she swerved into a ravine during a snowstorm and died in the freezing lake nearby, but a lightning strike suddenly revived her. From that moment on, Adaline has stayed physically 29 years old. One night, two suspicious FBI agents attempt to force her onto an airplane for study, but she escapes captivity and realizes that she will have to spend the rest of her life on the run. Ever since, she has changed her identification and address according to the era, while her daughter Flemming ages normally, to the point where she appears older than Adaline. On [[New Year's Eve]] in the present year, she attends a party where she meets Ellis Jones, introducing herself as her current alias, Jennifer. He asks to see her again but she refuses, knowing she can never fall in love because she can never have a normal future with someone. The next day at work, Ellis arrives and again asks Adaline to go on a date with him. Finally she accepts. In a flashback, Adaline is shown pulling up in a cab to a park where a man is waiting, holding an engagement ring. Scared, she asks the cab driver to keep going. Back in the present day, Adaline's dog falls ill and she begins to ignore Ellis' calls. He shows up at her apartment but she pushes him away, only to have a change of heart while looking through some old photographs and realizing she doesn't want to live the same year a hundred times without having a natural life. They later resolve their argument and Ellis asks Adaline to attend the party at his parents' house celebrating his parents' fortieth anniversary, and she says yes. Upon their arrival, Ellis introduces her to his father, William, who recognizes her instantly and calls her Adaline. She appears to recognize him, too, but lies, telling him that Adaline was her mother, who has since died. A flashback shows how they met and came to be in love, soon revealing that he was the man with the engagement ring she stood up that afternoon. One night, Ellis tells Adaline he is falling in love with her and she is unsure of how to react. The following day, Adaline talks with William outside and he notices a scar on her left hand, and becomes shaken. Another flashback reveals that Adaline cut her hand while they were hiking decades ago and he had stitched it up himself. He realizes that she is truly Adaline and confronts her. She becomes upset, claiming she used to be "normal" and doesn't know what changed her. He begs her not to run, for Ellis' sake, but she says she doesn't know how to stay. She flees and returns to the house, writing a note to Ellis while he showers, then she packs her things and leaves. Moments later, Ellis finds the letter and confronts his father, who refuses to explain. While driving home, Adaline thinks of all the times she has run and suddenly has a change of heart about the way she lives her life. She stops and calls her daughter to tell her she is going to stop running. As she turns the car around, a tow truck plows into her in a hit-and-run accident, leaving her to die. Freezing and helpless, Adaline dies again. An ambulance arrives and she is revived by the electricity of the defibrillator. Later in the hospital, she wakes up to Ellis, and the two profess their love for one another. Adaline then tells him of her 107 years of life. One year later, Ellis and Adaline are going to a New Year's Eve party. As she is leaving, she notices something strange in the hallway mirror: her first grey hair, proving she has begun to age naturally again. When Ellis asks if she is okay, she responds: "Yes... Perfect." ==Cast== *[[Blake Lively]] as Adaline Bowman / Jennifer "Jenny" Larson *[[Michiel Huisman]] as Ellis Jones *[[Harrison Ford]] as William Jones{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/harrison-ford-joins-age-adaline-671255/|title=Harrison Ford Joins 'Age of Adaline'|publisher=The Hollywood Reporter|date=January 15, 2014 |accessdate=November 4, 2014}} **[[Anthony Ingruber]] as young William *[[Ellen Burstyn]] as Flemming Prescott **Izabel Pearce as Young Flemming *[[Kathy Baker]] as Kathy Jones *[[Amanda Crew]] as Kikki Jones *[[Lynda Boyd]] as Regan *[[Anjali Jay]] as Cora *[[Richard Harmon]] as Tony *Mark Ghanimé as Caleb *[[Barclay Hope]] as Stanley Chesterfield *[[Chris William Martin]] as Dale Davenport *[[Hiro Kanagawa]] as Kenneth *Lane Edwards as Dr. Larry Levyne *Peter J. Gray as Clarence James *Jane Craven as Miriam Prescott{{cite web|last1=Peter|first1=Gray|title=SHOOT: THE AGE OF ADALINE With Adaline’s Husband (Peter J. Gray)|url=http://yvrshoots.com/2014/05/shoot-age-of-adaline-with-adalines-husband-on-burnabys-barnet-beach.html#.U7RV8xzxYk8|website=yvrshoots.com|publisher=YVRshoots|accessdate=July 2, 2014}} ==Production== On May 12, 2010 it was announced that ''The Age of Adaline'' would be co-financed and co-produced by [[Lakeshore Entertainment]] and [[Sidney Kimmel Entertainment]]. [[Salvador Paskowitz]] and [[J. Mills Goodloe]] wrote the script. Sierra / Affinity has the international rights, while producers were [[Steve Golin]], Alix Madigan, [[Tom Rosenberg]] and [[Gary Lucchesi]]. On July 20, 2010 it was reported that [[Andy Tennant]] was set to direct the film.{{cite news|last=Kilday|first=Gregg|title='Bounty Hunter' director tapped for 'Adaline'|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/imdb/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1004105215&vnu_special_account_code=thrsiteimdbpro|accessdate=February 12, 2014|newspaper=hollywoodreporter.com|date=July 20, 2010}} On October 31, 2010, [[Summit Entertainment]] bought the US distribution rights to the film, which was set to begin shooting in March 2011 for an early 2012 release.{{cite news|last=DiOrio|first=Carl|title=Summit Nabs Rights to Katherine Heigl Film 'Adaline'|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/summit-nabs-rights-katherine-heigl-33922|accessdate=February 12, 2014|newspaper=hollywoodreporter.com|date=October 31, 2010}} On February 22, 2011, it was reported that [[Gabriele Muccino]] was in talks to direct the film, replacing Tennant, with the film re-titled from ''The Age of Adaline'' to simply ''Adaline''.{{cite news|last=Anderton|first=Ethan|title=Gabriele Muccino in Talks to Direct Supernatural Romance 'Adaline'|url=http://www.firstshowing.net/2011/gabriele-muccino-in-talks-to-direct-supernatural-romance-adaline/|accessdate=February 12, 2014|newspaper=firstshowing.net|date=February 22, 2011}} On May 14, 2012, it was announced that Spanish director [[Isabel Coixet]] would direct the film instead.{{cite news|last=Kit|first=Borys|title='Elegy' Director Boards Fantasy Romance 'Age of Adaline'|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/elegy-director-Isabel-Coixet-age-of-adaline-324102|accessdate=February 12, 2014|newspaper=hollywoodreporter.com|date=May 14, 2012}} On October 16, 2013, [[Lee Toland Krieger]] was reported to be the actual director of the film. Producer Dan Cohen had shown him the script at a general meeting in 2009.{{cite web|last1=Solomon|first1=Dan|title=The Director Of "The Age of Adaline" On Bringing A Dream Project To Life|url=http://www.fastcocreate.com/3045324/the-director-of-age-of-adaline-on-bringing-a-dream-project-to-life|website=[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]]|accessdate=August 9, 2015|date=April 24, 2015}} ===Casting=== On May 12, 2010, [[Katherine Heigl]] was cast as the title character.{{cite news|last=Kit|first=Borys|title=Katherine Heigl to star in 'Age of Adaline'|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/imdb/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1004090861&vnu_special_account_code=thrsiteimdbpro|accessdate=February 12, 2014|newspaper=hollywoodreporter.com|date=May 12, 2010}} On November 12, 2010, [[Angela Lansbury]] was added to the cast of the film, set to play the daughter of the ageless Adaline.{{cite news|last=Fleming Jr|first=Mike|title=Angela Lansbury To Play Katherine Heigl's Daughter In 'Adaline'|url=http://www.deadline.com/2010/11/katherine-heigls-daughter-cast-in-adaline/|accessdate=February 12, 2014|newspaper=deadline.com|date=November 12, 2010}} On November 15, Heigl withdrew from ''Adaline'''s cast, and there were rumors that she had been fired by Lakeshore, which both Lakeshore and Heigl denied.{{cite news|last=Fleming Jr|first=Mike|title=Katherine Heigl Out Of ‘Adaline’|url=http://www.deadline.com/2010/11/katherine-heigl-out-of-adaline/|accessdate=February 12, 2014|newspaper=deadline.com|date=November 15, 2010}} She later announced that her withdrawal was a result of her recent adoption of a daughter. On August 15, 2011, [[TheWrap.com|TheWrap]] reported that [[Natalie Portman]] had been offered the lead role.{{cite news|last=L. Weinstein|first=Joshua|title=Natalie Portman Offered Lead Role in Indie Drama 'Adaline'|url=http://www.thewrap.com/column-post/natalie-portman-offered-lead-role-adaline-30125|accessdate=February 12, 2014|work=[[TheWrap]]|date=August 15, 2011}} On August 25, Portman told ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' that she had declined the offer.{{cite news|last=Markovitz|first=Adam|title=Natalie Portman turns down 'Adaline' role|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2011/08/26/natalie-portman-adaline/|accessdate=February 12, 2014|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=August 25, 2011}} On October 16, 2013, [[Blake Lively]] and [[Ellen Burstyn]] were cast in the film to play the lead roles, with Lively starring as the title character.{{cite news|last=Fleming Jr|first=Mike|title=Blake Lively, Ellen Burstyn Set To Star In ‘The Age Of Adaline’|url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/10/blake-lively-ellen-burstyn-set-to-star-in-the-age-of-adaline/|accessdate=February 12, 2014|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=October 16, 2013}} On January 15, 2014 [[Harrison Ford]] joined the cast, and the film was set to begin shooting in March of that year.{{cite news|last=Sneider|first=Jeff|title=Harrison Ford Joins Blake Lively, Ellen Burstyn in Drama ‘Age of Adaline’|url=http://www.thewrap.com/harrison-ford-joins-blake-lively-ellen-burstyn-drama-age-adaline/|accessdate=February 12, 2014|work=[[TheWrap]]|date=January 15, 2014}} On February 11, 2014 [[Michiel Huisman]] joined the cast to star opposite Lively as Adaline's love interest.{{cite news|title=Michiel Huisman To Co-Star Opposite Blake Lively In ‘Age Of Adaline’|url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/02/michiel-huisman-age-of-adeline-movie-blake-lively/|accessdate=February 12, 2014|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=February 11, 2014}} ===Filming=== Filming began on March 10, 2014 in [[Vancouver]] and continued through May 5.{{cite news|title=START DATE: AGE OF ADALINE with Blake Lively as Immortal Woman Expected to Start Filming March 10th|url=http://yvrshoots.com/2014/02/start-date-the-age-of-adaline-with-blake-lively-as-ageless-woman-expected-to-start-march-10th.html#.Uv7mGfmSyok|accessdate=February 15, 2014|newspaper=yvrshoots.com|date=February 11, 2014}} On March 11, 2014 filming at the [[Hotel Vancouver]] commenced.{{cite news|title=‘Age of Adaline’, starring Blake Lively, begins filming in Vancouver|url=http://www.onlocationvacations.com/2014/03/11/age-of-adaline-starring-blake-lively-begins-filming-in-vancouver/|accessdate=March 12, 2014|newspaper=onlocationvacations.com|date=March 11, 2014}} [[Anamorphic]] lenses and minimal use of [[steadicam]]s were employed to provide greater authenticity for scenes set in the 1930s, 1940s, and 1950s. The films ''[[Gentlemen Prefer Blondes (1953 film)|Gentlemen Prefer Blondes]]'' and ''[[How to Marry a Millionaire]]'' served as inspiration for the period color tone and saturation.{{cite web|title=The Age of Adaline - Movie production notes|url=http://www.cinemareview.com/production.asp?prodid=19995|website=CinemaReview.com|accessdate=August 9, 2015}} ===Music=== While Rob Simonsen scored the film, [[Lana Del Rey]] contributed a song titled "Life Is Beautiful". The song is featured in the film's trailer but is not included in the soundtrack. ==Release== On August 15, 2014, Lionsgate set the film for a January 23, 2015 worldwide release.{{cite news|title=Lionsgate Dates ‘L'age de Adaline’|url=http://deadline.com/2014/08/lionsgate-dates-the-age-of-adaline-2015-820050/|accessdate=August 15, 2014|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=August 15, 2014}} Later, the date was moved to April 24, 2015.{{cite news|last1=Lang|first1=Brent|title=Johnny Depp Comedy ‘Mortdecai’ Shifts to January 2015 Release Date|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/johnny-depp-comedy-mortdecai-shifts-to-january-2015-release-date-1201313324/|accessdate=September 25, 2014|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=Variety Media, LLC|date=September 24, 2014}} The film was released on DVD on September 8, 2015. ===Marketing=== The promotional campaign was aimed primarily at fashion-conscious women. Danielle DePalma, executive vice-president of digital marketing at Lionsgate, said, "We were very aware of Blake’s high-fashion profile when we crafted the campaign, and there was so much beautiful imagery from the film." They created vignettes for [[MTV]] and [[VH1]] and a fashion segment for [[E! News]] showing viewers how to achieve the same looks as Lively. They created a custom "Fashion Journey Through the Decades" initiative, through which a fashion influencer from [[YouTube]] or [[Maker Studios]] created a unique look inspired by the film. Video ads were also released on [[Instagram]] and tutorials on [[Pinterest]]. Advance screenings for fashion and lifestyle influencers took place in partnership with [[Gilt City]]. The application [[Periscope (app)|Periscope]] was used to spread information about the film.{{cite web|last1=Cunningham|first1=Todd|title=How Blake Lively’s Iconic Fashion Gave ‘Age of Adaline’ a Big Boost|url=http://www.thewrap.com/how-blake-livelys-iconic-fashion-gave-age-of-adaline-a-big-boost/|website=The Wrap|accessdate=August 9, 2015|date=April 28, 2015}} ==Reception== ===Box office=== ''The Age of Adaline'' earned $42,629,776 in North America and $23,033,500 in other countries, for a worldwide box office gross of $65.7 million.{{cite web |url= http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=ageofadaline.htm|title=The Age of Adaline (2015) |publisher= [[Box Office Mojo]] }} The film opened with $575,000 during Thursday late-night showings at 2,100 U.S. theaters.{{cite web|last1=McNary|first1=Dave|title=Box Office: ‘Age of Adaline’ Launches with $575,000 in Latenight Shows|url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/age-of-adaline-blake-lively-box-office-1201479171/|website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|accessdate=August 9, 2015|date=April 24, 2015}} It finished the weekend at number three behind ''[[Furious 7]]'' and ''[[Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2]]'' with $13.4 million from 2,991 locations.{{cite web|last1=Lang|first1=Brent|title=Box Office: ‘Furious 7′ Races Past ‘Age of Adaline’|url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/furious-7-box-office-age-of-adaline-1201480114/|website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=Variety Media, LLC|accessdate=August 9, 2015|date=April 26, 2015}} ===Critical response=== ''The Age of Adaline'' has received mixed reviews from critics, although the performances of Blake Lively and Harrison Ford received very positive reviews and were cited as some of their best work in recent years.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/apr/22/age-of-adaline-review-blake-lively-harrison-ford|title= The Age of Adaline review|work=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=[[Guardian News and Media]]|accessdate=May 9, 2015|date=April 22, 2015}} On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film has a rating of 56%, based on 150 reviews, with an average rating of 5.5/10. The site's consensus reads "''The Age of Adaline'' ruminates on mortality less compellingly than similarly themed films, but is set apart by memorable performances from Blake Lively and Harrison Ford."{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/the_age_of_adaline/|title=The Age of Adaline (2015)|work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|publisher=[[Fandango (company)|Fandango]]|accessdate=November 22, 2018}} On [[Metacritic]], the film has a score of 51 out of 100, based on 32 critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews".{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/the-age-of-adaline|title=The Age of Adaline|work=[[Metacritic]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive|CBS Interactive Inc.]]|accessdate=November 22, 2018}} In [[CinemaScore]] polls conducted during the opening weekend, cinema audiences gave ''The Age of Adaline'' an average grade of "A−" on an A+ to F scale.{{cite web|url=http://www.thewrap.com/age-of-adaline-overhauls-furious-7-at-friday-box-office/|title=‘Age of Adaline’ Overhauls ‘Furious 7’ at Friday Box Office|work=[[TheWrap]]|accessdate=April 26, 2015|author=Cunningham, Todd}} [[Matt Zoller Seitz]] of [[RogerEbert.com]] gave the film three out of four stars, expressing surprise at the film's increase in quality midway through: "I've never seen a less involving movie become so compelling at the exact moment when you've resigned to write it off as just okay." He also gave high praise to Harrison Ford's dramatic performance, writing that "Ford's voice—always deep, lowered an octave by age and one more by William's longing—is even more powerful [than the devastating look on his face]. This is Ford's best performance since ''[[The Fugitive (1993 film)|The Fugitive]]'', maybe since ''[[Witness (1985 film)|Witness]]''".{{cite web|last1=Seitz|first1=Matt Zoller Seitz|authorlink1=Matt Zoller Seitz|title=The Age of Adaline Movie Review (2015)|url=https://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/the-age-of-adaline-2015|website=[[RogerEbert.com]]|publisher=Ebert Digital LLC|accessdate=23 December 2017|date=24 April 2015}} ==Accolades== {{Anchor|Awards}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Award ! Category ! Recipient(s) ! Result ! Ref(s) |- | rowspan="3"| [[2015 Teen Choice Awards|Teen Choice Awards]] | colspan="2"| [[Teen Choice Award for Choice Movie – Drama|Choice Movie: Drama]] | {{nom}} | rowspan="3"| {{cite web|url=http://www.teenchoice.com/article/winners-of-%E2%80%9Cteen-choice-2015%E2%80%9D-announced|title=WINNERS OF TEEN CHOICE 2015 ANNOUNCED|work=[[Teen Choice Awards]]|publisher=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|FOX]]|date=August 16, 2015|accessdate=August 17, 2015}} |- | Choice Movie Actress: Drama | [[Blake Lively]] | {{nom}} |- | Choice Movie: Liplock | Blake Lively and [[Michiel Huisman]] | {{nom}} |- | The Joey Awards | Young Actress in a Television | Izabel Pearce | {{nom}} | |- | rowspan="2"| [[42nd People's Choice Awards|People's Choice Awards]] | colspan="2"| Favorite Dramatic Movie | {{nom}} | rowspan="2"| {{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/peoples-choice-awards-2016-winners-and-highlights/|title=2016 Winners and highlights|date=6 January 2016|work=CBS News|accessdate=7 January 2016}}{{cite web |title = List: Who won People's Choice Awards? |url = https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/people/2016/01/06/peoples-choice-awards-winners/78391812/ |website = [[USA Today]] |date = January 6, 2016 |accessdate = January 6, 2016 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6eLlWsxti |archivedate = January 6, 2016 |deadurl = no }} |- | Favorite Dramatic Movie Actress | Blake Lively | {{nom}} |- | rowspan="2"| [[42nd Saturn Awards|Saturn Awards]] | colspan="2"| [[Saturn Award for Best Fantasy Film|Best Fantasy Film]] | {{nom}} | rowspan="2"| {{cite web|url=http://www.saturnawards.org/|title=The 42nd Annual Saturn Awards nominations are announced for 2016!|publisher=[[Saturn Award]]s|date=February 24, 2016|accessdate=March 4, 2016}} |- | [[Saturn Award for Best Actress|Best Actress]] | Blake Lively | {{nom}} |} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|1655441}} *{{AllMovie title|593588}} *{{Mojo title|ageofadaline}} *{{Metacritic film|the-age-of-adaline}} *{{Rotten Tomatoes|the_age_of_adaline}} {{Lee Toland Krieger}} {{Portalbar|Film in the United States|2010s}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Age Of Adaline, The}} [[Category:2015 films]] [[Category:2010s coming-of-age films]] [[Category:2010s romantic drama films]] [[Category:2010s romantic fantasy films]] [[Category:American coming-of-age films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American romantic drama films]] [[Category:American romantic fantasy films]] [[Category:Fantasy drama films]] [[Category:Films about dysfunctional families]] [[Category:Films about human rights]] [[Category:Films about old age]] [[Category:Films directed by Lee Toland Krieger]] [[Category:Films produced by Gary Lucchesi]] [[Category:Films produced by Sidney Kimmel]] [[Category:Films produced by Tom Rosenberg]] [[Category:Films set in San Francisco]] [[Category:Films shot in Vancouver]] [[Category:Immortality in fiction]] [[Category:Lakeshore Entertainment films]] [[Category:Love stories]] [[Category:Sidney Kimmel Entertainment films]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2016}} {{Use British English|date=June 2016}} {{Infobox film | name = The Falling | image = TheFalling2014Poster.jpg | caption = UK theatrical release poster | director = [[Carol Morley]] | producer = {{plainlist| * [[Luc Roeg]] * [[Cairo Cannon]] }} | writer = Carol Morley | starring = {{plainlist| * [[Maisie Williams]] * [[Maxine Peake]] * [[Monica Dolan]] * [[Greta Scacchi]] * [[Mathew Baynton]] * [[Florence Pugh]] }} | music = [[Tracey Thorn]] | cinematography = [[Agnes Godard]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/TheFalling_Film/status/572395654091300865 |title=''The Falling'' |work=[[Twitter]] |accessdate=24 March 2015}}</ref> | editing = Chris Wyatt | studio = {{plainlist| * [[BBC Films]] * [[British Film Institute]] }} | distributor = Metrodome UK | released = {{film date|df=yes|2014|10|11|London Film Festival}} | runtime = 102 minutes | country = United Kingdom | language = English | budget = £750,000<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cineuropa.org/nw.aspx?t=newsdetail&l=en&did=246205 |title=Carol Morley begins ''The Falling'' |work=Cineuropa.org |accessdate=8 October 2014}}</ref> | gross = £468,762<ref>{{cite news |title=United Kingdom, US New Zealand Box Office |url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movie/Falling-The/New-Zealand#tab=international |work=[[The Numbers (website)|The Numbers]] |date=12 January 2016}}</ref> }} '''''The Falling''''' is a 2014 British mystery [[drama film]] written and directed by [[Carol Morley]]. It stars [[Maisie Williams]] and [[Florence Pugh]] as best friends at an all-girls school. The film also stars [[Greta Scacchi]], [[Monica Dolan]], [[Maxine Peake]], and [[Mathew Baynton]]. Production began in October 2013. The film premiered at the [[BFI London Film Festival]] on 11 October 2014 and was released theatrically on 24 April 2015 in the UK. ''The Falling'' earned £468,762 on a £750,000 budget.
== Plot == In 1969, Lydia and Abbie are best friends at an English girls school. Lydia, the neglected daughter of an [[agoraphobic]] mother, becomes fixated on Abbie, who has begun to explore her sexuality. After having sex with Lydia's brother Kenneth in an attempt to abort her pregnancy by another boy, Abbie begins to suffer from [[Mass psychogenic illness|fainting spells]]. She suffers an episode after a stint in detention with Lydia and dies in the process. Following Abbie's burial, Lydia begins suffering as well from fainting spells, and it soon becomes an epidemic, with numerous girls and a young teacher in the school spontaneously passing out for no more than a few seconds. Lydia becomes convinced that the administration must take action, much to the chagrin of the school principal.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/bbcfilms/articles/the_falling_begins_shoot |title=Independent Announces Start of Shoot for Carol Morley's Film ''The Falling'' |work=[[BBC Films]] |accessdate=8 October 2014}}</ref>
When an assembly becomes disrupted by a mass fainting episode, the school is temporarily shut down and all affected students are hospitalized and psychoanalysed. When no cause for the spells is discovered, the school is reopened and Lydia is expelled. That same night, the virginal Lydia has sex with Kenneth, with whom she has developed an incestuous relationship after Abbie's death. However their mother Eileen catches them and, armed with a pair of scissors, angrily forces Kenneth out of the house before launching into an argument with her daughter, in which she brands Lydia dangerous and that she ought to be locked up. Eileen also reveals that Lydia and Kenneth are only half-siblings; Lydia being the product of a rape.
Upon learning this, Lydia runs out of the house and Eileen follows her outside, despite having never ventured outside in over 16 years. Searching for Lydia, Eileen is overcome with flashbacks of her own sexual assault, and eventually locates Lydia; who has climbed to the top of a tree in a breakdown over Abbie's death. Eileen pleads with Lydia to come down, but she laughs, challenging her mother's lack of maternal affection, before losing her footing and leaping from the tree into a lake.
Distraught, Eileen ventures into the water and cradles Lydia's seemingly drowned body, realizing that her emotional frigidity had done more harm to her daughter than she knew. Lydia regains consciousness, and the film ends with the two women in a crying embrace.
== Cast == * [[Maisie Williams]] as Lydia Lamont * [[Maxine Peake]] as Eileen Lamb * [[Monica Dolan]] as Miss Alvaro * [[Greta Scacchi]] as Miss Mantel * [[Mathew Baynton]] as Mr Hopkins * [[Florence Pugh]] as Abigail Mortimer * [[Joe Cole (actor)|Joe Cole]] as Kenneth Lamont * [[Lauren McCrostie]] as Gwen * [[Rose Caton]] as Titch
== Production == BFI funded the film £750K.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.screendaily.com/news/get-santa-bill-get-1m-from-bfi/5063873.article |title=Get Santa, Bill get £1m from BFI |last=Wiseman |first=Andreas |work=[[Screen Daily]] |date=21 November 2013 |accessdate=8 October 2014}}</ref> Production began in October 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.screendaily.com/news/carol-morleys-falling-underway/5062960.article |title=Carol Morley's ''The Falling'' underway |last=Wiseman |first=Andreas |work=[[Screen Daily]] |date=28 October 2013 |accessdate=8 October 2014}}</ref>
The soundtrack is by [[Tracey Thorn]]. Morley asked Thorn to provide the music for the film after editing had begun.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/apr/21/carol-morley-tracey-thorn-the-falling|title=Carol Morley and Tracey Thorn: "Girls' schools? They’re a hotpot of urges"|author=Peter Bradshaw|work=the Guardian}}</ref>
== Release == ''The Falling'' premiered at the [[BFI London Film Festival]] on 11 October 2014.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/testament-of-youth-to-world-premiere-at-london-film-festival-1201296658 |title=''Testament of Youth'' to World Premiere at London Film Festival |last=Barraclough |first=Leo |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=3 September 2014 |accessdate=8 October 2014}}</ref> It had a limited release in the United Kingdom, grossing £442,177 with a further £10,051 grossed in New Zealand.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movie/Falling-The/New-Zealand#tab=international=summary |title=New Zealand Box Office for The Falling (2015)|work=The Numbers}}</ref> US DVD sales amounted to another £6,406.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.screendaily.com/news/metrodome-catches-carol-morleys-the-falling/5076917.article |title=Metrodome catches Carol Morley's ''The Falling'' |last=Wiseman |first=Andreas |work=[[Screen Daily]] |date=2 September 2014 |accessdate=8 October 2014}}</ref>
== Reception == [[Rotten Tomatoes]], a [[review aggregator]], reports that 78% of 22 surveyed critics gave the film a positive review; the average rating is 7/10.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/the_falling_2014/|title=The Falling (2015)|work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|accessdate=21 May 2015}}</ref> Mark Adams of ''[[Screen International]]'' wrote, "It is a film that will resonate with some but leave others exasperated, but ''The Falling'' is certainly a bold film, and one to be admired and appreciated."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.screendaily.com/reviews/the-latest/the-falling/5078546.article|title=The Falling|last=Adams|first=Mark|work=[[Screen International]]|date=11 October 2014|accessdate=24 April 2015}}</ref> Guy Lodge of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' called it "an imperfect but alluring study of psychological contagion that marks an auspicious advance in the field of narrative filmmaking for acclaimed documaker Carol Morley".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/festivals/london-film-review-the-falling-1201331977/|title=London Film Review: ‘The Falling’|last=Lodge|first=Guy|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=17 October 2014|accessdate=24 April 2015}}</ref> Leslie Felperin of ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' called it "a flawed but fascinating period study of female friendship and hysteria".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/falling-london-review-740347|title=‘The Falling’: London Review|last=Felperin|first=Leslie|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=13 October 2014|accessdate=24 April 2015}}</ref> Trevor Johnston of ''[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out London]]'' rated it 4/5 stars and wrote, "Carol Morley shows startling versatility and ambition with this jawdropping mash-up of ''[[If...|If]]'' and ''[[Picnic at Hanging Rock (film)|Picnic at Hanging Rock]]''".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timeout.com/london/film/the-falling|title=The Falling|last=Johnston|first=Trevor|work=[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out London]]|date=20 April 2015|accessdate=24 April 2015}}</ref> Mike McCahill of ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' rated it 4/5 stars and called it a continuation of the themes in [[Nicolas Roeg]]'s ''[[Performance (film)|Performance]]'' and ''[[Don't Look Now]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/film/the-falling/review/|title=The Falling review: 'potently suggestive'|last=McCahill|first=Mike|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=24 April 2015|accessdate=24 April 2015}}</ref>
Geoffrey Macnab of ''[[The Independent]]'' rated it 4/5 stars and wrote, "Carol Morley's ''The Falling'' is beguiling and disturbing, a beautifully made and very subtle affair that combines melodrama, rites of passage and supernatural elements in an utterly intriguing way."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/reviews/the-falling-film-review-top-of-the-class-for-melodrama-and-mystery-10199794.html|title=The Falling, film review: Maisie Williams is top of the class for melodrama and mystery|last=Macnab|first=Geoffrey|work=[[The Independent]]|date=24 April 2015|accessdate=24 April 2015}}</ref> [[Peter Bradshaw]] of ''[[The Guardian]]'' rated it 5/5 stars and wrote, "Director Carol Morley has come up with another brilliant and very distinctive feature, about an epidemic of fainting that grips a girls school in the 1960s."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/oct/10/the-falling-review-london-film-festival-carol-morley|title=The Falling review – Carol Morley's masterly followup to Dreams of a Life|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=10 October 2014|accessdate=24 April 2015}}</ref> Elise Nakhnikian of ''[[Slant Magazine]]'' gave a less favourable review, writing that "the film all leads to a melodramatic climax that wraps up the main character's explosive acting out in a too-neat package."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slantmagazine.com/film/review/the-falling|title=The Falling|author=Elise Nakhnikian|date=23 August 2015|work=Slant Magazine}}</ref> David Jenkins of ''[[Little White Lies (magazine)|Little White Lies]]'' also gave an unfavourable review, writing, "Carol Morley follows up the mesmerising [[Dreams of a Life]] with a tedious period drama set in an all-girls school."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.littlewhitelies.co.uk/theatrical-reviews/the-falling-29408 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150919090744/http://www.littlewhitelies.co.uk/theatrical-reviews/the-falling-29408 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2015-09-19 |title=The Falling review |author=Little White Lies magazine|work=littlewhitelies.co.uk}}</ref>
== Awards == {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Award ! Category ! Nominee ! Result |- | [[London Film Festival]] 2014 | Best British Newcomer and Best Film || Florence Pugh and Official Competition Carol Morley || {{Nominated}} |- | [[London Film Critics' Circle]] || Young British/Irish Performer Of The Year || Maisie Williams<ref>http://www.criticscircle.org.uk/film/?ID=479</ref> || {{won}} |- | [[Evening Standard British Film Awards]] || Rising Star || Maisie Williams<ref>https://www.standard.co.uk/goingout/film/evening-standard-british-film-awards-2016-idris-elba-and-dame-maggie-smith-lead-list-of-winners-a3174206.html</ref> || {{won}} |- |}

revision.text:
{{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Umbilical cord prolapse | synonyms = | image = Cord.prolaps.jpg | caption = Cord prolapse, as depicted in 1792 | pronounce = | field = [[Obstetrics]] | symptoms = | complications = | onset = | duration = | types = | causes = | risks = Abnormal position of the baby, [[premature birth|prematurity]], twin pregnancy, multiple prior pregnancies<ref name=GLOWM2017/><ref name=Say2018/> | diagnosis = Suspected based on a sudden decrease in babies heart rate during labor, confirmed by seeing or feeling the cord in the vagina<ref name=Hol2013/> | differential = [[Abruptio placentae]]<ref name=GLOWM2017/> | prevention = | treatment = Rapid delivery, usually by [[cesarean section]].<ref name=Hol2013/> | medication = | prognosis = Risk of death of the baby 10%<ref name=GLOWM2017/> | frequency = < 1% of pregnancies<ref name=Hol2013/> | deaths = }} <!-- Definition and symptoms --> '''Umbilical cord prolapse''' is when, during [[Childbirth|labor]], the [[umbilical cord]] comes out of the [[uterus]] with or before the presenting part of the [[baby]].<ref name=GLOWM2017/> The concern with cord prolapse is that pressure on the cord from the baby will compromising [[blood]] flow to the baby.<ref name=GLOWM2017/>
<!-- Cause and diagnosis --> The greatest risk factor is having had more than two previous children with the current baby in an abnormally positioned within the uterus.<ref name=Say2018>{{cite journal |last1=Sayed Ahmed |first1=WA |last2=Hamdy |first2=MA |title=Optimal management of umbilical cord prolapse. |journal=International Journal of Women's Health |date=2018 |volume=10 |pages=459–465 |doi=10.2147/IJWH.S130879 |pmid=30174462|pmc=6109652 }}</ref> Other risks include a [[Premature birth|premature]] or small baby, [[twin pregnancy]], and [[too much amniotic fluid]].<ref name=GLOWM2017/><ref name=Say2018/> Whether [[amniotomy|medical rupture of the amniotic sac]] is a risk is controversial.<ref name=GLOWM2017/><ref name=Say2018/> The diagnosis should be suspected if there is a sudden decrease in the babies heart rate during labor.<ref name=Hol2013/> Seeing or feeling the cord confirms the diagnosis.<ref name=Hol2013/>
<!-- Treatment and prognosis --> Management focuses on quick delivery, usually by [[cesarean section]].<ref name=Hol2013/> Filling the bladder or pushing up the baby by hand is recommended until this can take place.<ref name=Hol2013/> The [[knee-chest position]], or if this is not possible [[Trendelenburg position]] may be used.<ref name=GLOWM2017/> With appropriate management, the majority of cases have good outcomes.<ref name=Hol2013/>
<!-- Epidemiology --> Umbilical cord prolapse occurs in about 1 in 500 pregnancies.<ref name=GLOWM2017>{{cite journal |last1=Lore |first1=Marybeth |title=Umbilical Cord Prolapse and Other Cord Emergencies |journal=The Global Library of Women's Medicine |date=March 2017 |doi=10.3843/GLOWM.10136}}</ref> The risk of death of the baby is about 10%.<ref name=GLOWM2017/> Much of this risk is due to [[congenital anomalies]] or [[premature birth|prematurity]], however.<ref name=GLOWM2017/> It is considered an emergency.<ref name=Hol2013>{{cite journal |last1=Holbrook |first1=BD |last2=Phelan |first2=ST |title=Umbilical cord prolapse. |journal=Obstetrics and Gynecology Clinics of North America |date=March 2013 |volume=40 |issue=1 |pages=1–14 |doi=10.1016/j.ogc.2012.11.002 |pmid=23466132}}</ref>
==Signs and symptoms== The first sign of umbilical cord prolapse is usually a sudden [[bradycardia|decrease in fetal heart rate]] that is severe and does not immediately resolve. On a fetal heart tracing, this would usually look like moderate to severe [[cardiotocography#deceleration|variable decelerations]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Tejani|first1=NA|last2=Mann|first2=LI|last3=Sanghavi|first3=M|last4=Bhakthavathsalan|first4=A|last5=Weiss|first5=RR|title=The association of umbilical cord complications and variable decelerations with acid-base findings.|journal=Obstetrics and Gynecology|date=February 1977|volume=49|issue=2|pages=159–62|pmid=13333}}</ref> Occasionally, the cord can be seen or felt on vaginal examination, particularly with overt cord prolapse.
==Risk factors== Risk factors that are associated with umbilical cord prolapse tend to make it difficult for the fetus from appropriately engaging and filling the maternal pelvis or are related to abnormalities of the umbilical cord. The two major categories of risk factors are spontaneous and [[iatrogenesis|iatrogenic]], or those that result from medical intervention. * '''spontaneous factors''': ** fetal malpresentation:<ref name="kahana">{{cite journal|last1=Kahana|first1=B|last2=Sheiner|first2=E|last3=Levy|first3=A|last4=Lazer|first4=S|last5=Mazor|first5=M|title=Umbilical cord prolapse and perinatal outcomes.|journal=International Journal of Gynaecology and Obstetrics|date=February 2004|volume=84|issue=2|pages=127–32|pmid=14871514|doi=10.1016/s0020-7292(03)00333-3}}</ref> abnormal fetal lie tends to result in space below the fetus in the maternal pelvis, which can then be occupied by the cord. ** [[polyhydramnios]], or an abnormally high amount of amniotic fluid<ref name="kahana" /> ** [[premature birth|prematurity]]: likely related to increased chance of malpresentation and relative polyhydramnios.<ref name="kahana" /> ** [[low birth weight]]:<ref name="critchlow">{{cite journal|last1=Critchlow|first1=CW|last2=Leet|first2=TL|last3=Benedetti|first3=TJ|last4=Daling|first4=JR|title=Risk factors and infant outcomes associated with umbilical cord prolapse: a population-based case-control study among births in Washington State.|journal=American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology|date=February 1994|volume=170|issue=2|pages=613–8|pmid=8116723|doi=10.1016/s0002-9378(94)70238-1}}</ref> usually described as <2500 g at birth, though some studies will use <1500g. Cause is likely similar to those for prematurity. ** [[multiple gestation]], or being pregnant with more than one fetus at a given time:<ref name="critchlow" /> more likely to occur in the fetus that is not born first. ** spontaneous [[rupture of membranes]]:<ref name="murphy">{{cite journal|last1=Murphy|first1=DJ|last2=MacKenzie|first2=IZ|title=The mortality and morbidity associated with umbilical cord prolapse.|journal=British Journal of Obstetrics and Gynaecology|date=October 1995|volume=102|issue=10|pages=826–30|pmid=7547741|doi=10.1111/j.1471-0528.1995.tb10850.x}}</ref> about half of prolapses occur within 5 minutes of membrane rupture, two-thirds within 1 hour, 95% within 24 hours. * '''treatment associated factors''' ** [[artificial rupture of membranes]]<ref name="usta">{{cite journal|last1=Usta|first1=IM|last2=Mercer|first2=BM|last3=Sibai|first3=BM|title=Current obstetrical practice and umbilical cord prolapse.|journal=American Journal of Perinatology|date=1999|volume=16|issue=9|pages=479–84|pmid=10774764|doi=10.1055/s-1999-6809}}</ref> ** placement of internal monitors (for example, [[internal scalp electrode]] or [[intrauterine pressure catheter]])<ref name="usta" /> ** [[external cephalic version|manual rotation of fetal head]]<ref name="usta" />
==Diagnosis== Umbilical cord prolapse should always be considered a possibility when there is a sudden decrease in fetal heart rate or variable decelerations, particularly after the rupture of membranes. With overt prolapses, the diagnosis can be confirmed if the cord can be palpated on vaginal examination. Without overt prolapse, the diagnosis can only be confirmed after a [[cesarean section]], though even then it will not always be evident at time of procedure.<ref name="lin" />
===Classification=== There are three types of umbilical prolapse that can occur:<ref name="lin">{{cite journal|last1=Lin|first1=MG|title=Umbilical cord prolapse.|journal=Obstetrical & Gynecological Survey|date=April 2006|volume=61|issue=4|pages=269–77|pmid=16551378|doi=10.1097/01.ogx.0000208802.20908.c6}}</ref> * '''overt umbilical cord prolapse''': descent of the umbilical cord past the presenting fetal part. In this case, the cord is through the [[cervix]] and into or beyond the [[vagina]]. Overt umbilical cord prolapse requires rupture of membranes. This is the most common type of cord prolapse. * '''occult umbilical prolapse''': descent of the umbilical cord alongside the presenting fetal part, but has not advanced past the presenting fetal part. Occult umbilical prolapse can occur with both intact or ruptured membranes. * '''funic (cord) presentation''': presence of the umbilical cord between the presenting fetal part and fetal membranes. In this case, the cord has not passed the opening of the cervix. In funic presentation, the membranes are not yet ruptured.
==Management== [[File:Herself; talks with women concerning themselves (1911) (14781210692).jpg|thumb|The knee-chest position is typically recommended<ref name=GLOWM2017/>]]
The gold standard for treatment of umbilical cord prolapse in the setting of a [[fetal viability|viable pregnancy]] typically involves immediate delivery by the quickest and safest route possible. This usually requires cesarean section, especially if the woman is in early labor. Occasionally, vaginal delivery will be attempted if clinical judgment determines that is a safer or quicker method.<ref name="lin" />
Other interventions during management of cord prolapse are typically used to decrease the chance of complications while preparations for delivery are being made. These interventions are focused on reducing pressure on the cord to prevent fetal complications from cord compression. The following maneuvers are among those used in clinical practice: * manual elevation of the presenting fetal part <ref name="murphy" /><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Duval|first1=C|last2=Lemoine|first2=JP|last3=Ba|first3=S|last4=Demory|first4=JE|title=[Prolapse of the umbilical cord. 79 cases].|journal=Revue Francaise de Gynecologie et d'Obstetrique|date=March 1987|volume=82|issue=3|pages=163–7|pmid=3589354}}</ref> * repositioning of the mother to be [[trendelenburg position|head down with feet elevated]] * filling of the [[bladder]] by a [[foley catheter]] to elevate the presenting fetal part <ref name="lin" /> * use of [[tocolytic]]s (medications to suppress labor) have been proposed, usually in addition to bladder filling rather than a standalone intervention <ref>{{cite journal|last1=Katz|first1=Z|last2=Shoham|first2=Z|last3=Lancet|first3=M|last4=Blickstein|first4=I|last5=Mogilner|first5=BM|last6=Zalel|first6=Y|title=Management of labor with umbilical cord prolapse: a 5-year study.|journal=Obstetrics and Gynecology|date=August 1988|volume=72|issue=2|pages=278–81|pmid=3393364}}</ref>
If the mother is far from delivery, funic reduction (manually placing the cord back into the uterine cavity) has been attempted,<ref>{{cite book|last1=al.]|first1=ed. by Kate Grady ... [et|title=Managing obstetric emergencies and trauma : the MOET course manual.|date=2007|publisher=RCOG Press|location=London|isbn=978-1904752-219|edition=2nd}}</ref> with successful cases reported.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Barrett|first1=JM|title=Funic reduction for the management of umbilical cord prolapse.|journal=American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology|date=September 1991|volume=165|issue=3|pages=654–7|pmid=1892193|doi=10.1016/0002-9378(91)90303-9}}</ref>
==Outcomes== The primary concern with umbilical cord prolapse is inadequate blood supply, and thus oxygen, to the fetus if the cord becomes compressed. The cord can become compressed either due to mechanical pressure (usually from the presenting fetal part) or from [[vasospasm|sudden contraction of the vessels]] due to decreased temperatures in the vagina in comparison to the uterus.<ref name="lin" /> This can lead to [[perinatal mortality|death of the fetus]] or other complications.
Historically, the rate of fetal death in the setting of cord prolapse has been as high 40%.<ref name="koonings">{{cite journal|last1=Koonings|first1=PP|last2=Paul|first2=RH|last3=Campbell|first3=K|title=Umbilical cord prolapse. A contemporary look.|journal=The Journal of Reproductive Medicine|date=July 1990|volume=35|issue=7|pages=690–2|pmid=2376856}}</ref> However, these estimates occurred in the context of home or births outside of the hospital. When considering cord prolapses that have occurred in inpatient labor and delivery settings, the rate drops to as low as 0-3%,<ref name="lin" /> though the mortality rate remains higher than for fetuses without cord prolapse. The reduction in mortality for hospital births is likely due to the ready availability of immediate cesarean section.
Many other fetal outcomes have been studied, including [[Apgar score]] (a quick assessment of a newborn's health status) at 5 minutes and length of hospitalization after delivery. While both measures are worse for newborns delivered after cord prolapse,<ref name="kahana"/> it is unclear what effect this has in the long-term. Relatively large studies that have tried to quantify long-term effects of cord prolapse on children found that less than 1% (1 in 120 studied) suffered a major neurologic handicap,<ref name="murphy"/> and less than 1% (110 in 16,675) had diagnosed cerebral palsy.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gilbert|first1=WM|last2=Jacoby|first2=BN|last3=Xing|first3=G|last4=Danielsen|first4=B|last5=Smith|first5=LH|title=Adverse obstetric events are associated with significant risk of cerebral palsy.|journal=American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology|date=October 2010|volume=203|issue=4|pages=328.e1–5|pmid=20598283|doi=10.1016/j.ajog.2010.05.013|pmc=2947602}}</ref>
==Epidemiology== Rates of umbilical cord prolapse ranges from 0.1-0.6% of all pregnancies.<ref name="lin" /><ref name="koonings" /> This rate has remained stable over time. A recent study estimates 77% of cord prolapses occur in singleton pregnancies, or those where there is only one fetus. In twin pregnancies, cord prolapses occur more frequently in the second twin to be delivered, with 9% in the first twin and 14% in the second twin.<ref name="murphy" />

{{Refimprove|date=December 2009}} {{redirect|Win win}} A '''win–win game''' is a [[game]] that, in game design or [[game theory]], is designed in a way that all participants can profit from it in one way or the other. In [[conflict resolution]], a '''win–win strategy''' is a collaborative strategy and conflict resolution process that aims to accommodate all participants.<ref name=WWS-D-01/><ref name=WWS-D-02/><ref name=WWS-D-03/> In [[economics]], it is a voluntary transaction where both parties gain wealth, as in [[the double thank-you of capitalism]].
==Types== * In colloquial speech, a win–win situation often refers to a situation where one benefits, not necessarily through someone else's loss. * In the context of [[group-dynamic game]]s, win–win games are also called "[[cooperative game]]s", "new games" or "games without losers". * Mathematical [[game theory]] also refers to win–win games as [[non-zero-sum game]]s (although they may include situations where both players win or lose, as well). * The TKI Thomas/Kilmann Conflict Profile provides a model that reveals preferences under stress and pressure. [[Collaboration]] style focuses on win–win outcomes.
===Group dynamics=== Group-dynamics win–win games have been increasingly popular since the end of the Vietnam war and have been successfully applied to all levels of society.
Group-dynamics win–win games emphasize the importance of cooperation, fun, sharing, caring and overall group success in contrast to domination, egoistic behavior and personal gain. All players are treated as equally important and valuable. Win–win games often also carry an ethical message of caring for the environment and a [[holistic]] approach to life and society. Win–win games are a powerful tool to give people [[self-confidence]] and a "we" experience, especially when they have suffered from emotional isolation.
An example would be a game where all players try to carry a huge "earth ball" (a ball several meters in diameter) over their heads while negotiating an obstacle course. This is a typical example of a win–win game for several reasons: * There are no losers (everyone enjoys the accomplished task). * All players are involved (no-one is left out or sits out). * The game is psychologically working on many levels (communication, supporting each other, having fun in a group etc.)
There are also mathematical win–win games, the mathematical term being [[non-zero-sum games]]. Such games are often simply represented by a [[Matrix (mathematics)|matrix]] of payouts.
